content.text:
# 1972 United States presidential election in Minnesota

| election_date = November 7, 1972
| image_size = x200px
| image1 = Richard Nixon presidential portrait (1).jpg
| nominee1 = Richard Nixon
| party1 = Republican Party of Minnesota
| home_state1 = California
| running_mate1 = Spiro Agnew
| electoral_vote1 = 10
| popular_vote1 = 898,269
| percentage1 = 51.58%
| image2 = George McGovern (D-SD) (3x4-1).jpg
| nominee2 = George McGovern
| party2 = Minnesota Democratic–Farmer–Labor Party
| home_state2 = South Dakota
| running_mate2 = Sargent Shriver
| electoral_vote2 = 0
| popular_vote2 = 802,346
| percentage2 = 46.07%
| map_image =
| map_size = 320px

Nixon
McGovern
| title = President

| after_election = Richard Nixon
| after_party = Republican Party of Minnesota

The 1972 United States presidential election in Minnesota took place on November 7, 1972, as part of the 1972 United States presidential election. Voters chose ten electors, or representatives to the Electoral College, who voted for president and vice president.
Minnesota was won by the Republican candidate, incumbent President Richard Nixon, who won the state over U.S. Senator George McGovern of South Dakota by a margin of 95,923 votes, or 5.51%, the closest state in the election. This result made Minnesota around 18% more Democratic than the nation as a whole. Nixon went on to win the election nationally, by a landslide margin of 23.15% of the popular vote. McGovern carried only Massachusetts and the District of Columbia.
As of 2025, this is the last time Minnesota, a state that has generally favored Democrats since the New Deal, was carried by a Republican, as well as the last election in which the Midwest voted unanimously in the electoral college. Minnesota would go on to have the longest streak voting for Democrats out of any state after this election, as every other state would be won by Ronald Reagan in the landslide year of 1984. This is also the last time a Republican has won heavily populated Hennepin County, while Rice County would not vote Republican again until 2016 and Pine County until 2012. Nixon further became the first-ever Republican to win the White House without carrying Stevens County, which was one of six counties outside of McGovern's home state of South Dakota that he flipped nationwide. Had Nixon lost the state, then this would have been the first election in which a Republican won two terms to the presidency without carrying the state at least once, the first to do so since 1916 and Minnesota would have had the longest streak of any state voting for same party, as this is the only election since 1956 where a Republican presidential candidate won the state and did not go Democrat.
During Nixon's second term as president, the Watergate scandal resulted in the loss of the Republican Party's credibility both nationally and in Minnesota. The damage caused by Watergate was so pronounced that the Republican Party of Minnesota was forced to rebrand itself as the "Independent-Republican Party" from 1975 to 1995 to distance itself from the national Republican Party.
